Award.AwardTitle: Recycled Concrete Aggregates for New Concrete Buildings for sustainability

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Concrete is one of the most versatile building materials and has facilitated industrial growth in the last century. However, it is difficult to get rid of concrete waste when concrete buildings are demolished. Crushed old concrete is recycled as aggregates in highway pavements but it is not used in buildings and bridges because of uncertainties of performance of new concrete. If crushed old concrete can be recycled in new building construction it would help in getting rid of waste and preserve natural riverbed rocks. This project will pursue research in classifying old crushed concrete for its use as aggregate in new concrete for buildings and bridges. Properties such as strength, durability, long-term deformation will be determined for concrete made with recycled concrete. As the nations infrastructure goes through upgrading, the volume of available waste concrete will increase. Use of this waste concrete in new concrete will reduce environmental impact of storing the waste and preserving natural environment of riverbeds.

Structural concrete made with recycled concrete aggregates can have significant variability in the behavior of buildings and bridges regarding deformations, creep and durability. The project will pursue experimental and analytical research to seek answers to these questions: (1) what are the economic and environmental benefits of recycling concrete in structures? (2) what are the long-term service load and design load performances of structural members, including prestressed concrete members? (3) how do recycled concrete aggregates affect durability? and (4) what modifications, if any, need to be made to crushed concrete to enhance performance of new concrete? The project will assess mechanical properties of concrete made with crushed concrete as aggregates. Also, beams and columns made of recycled concrete will be tested in laboratory to establish performance of structural components. Ultimately, the project will develop performance-based requirements, mix design guidelines, acceptance tests, and structural design/analysis/construction guidelines to achieve acceptable performance of concrete members using recycled concrete aggregates.

Institution.Name: University of Notre Dame
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, which was conducted at the University of Notre Dame in collaboration with the University of Texas at Tyler, involved fundamental research on the structural use of recycled concrete aggregates (RCA) as coarse aggregates in new reinforced concrete construction. Concrete is the most widely used material on earth (after water) and reinforced concrete is the most commonly used structural system for buildings. As aggregates (e.g., crushed limestone, gravel) constitute the largest volumetric component of concrete, the sustainability of our infrastructure can be enhanced significantly by reducing demand for virgin aggregates (reduce resource depletion) and increasing utilization of existing deteriorated infrastructure (increase resource reuse). Direct outcomes of the project included the development of performance-based RCA qualification requirements, concrete mix design guidelines and acceptance tests, and structural design/analysis/construction specifications to achieve acceptable fresh and hardened, short-term as well as long-term performance considering the variability of RCA properties in the U.S. These activities considering the current research needs resulted in new technical knowledge, physical resources, know-how, and human resources as described below.

As one of the main intellectual outcomes, the project collected and tested the largest and most representative sample of RCA materials across the U.S., also making it the most geographically varied study of RCA known to the PIs. Using this data, predictive models previously developed for the compressive strength and stiffness of RCA concrete using materials from the Midwestern U.S. were extended to a much broader region of the country. As an additional significant outcome, this study demonstrated quantitatively and rigorously the environmental benefits and economic viability of RCA over natural aggregates.

Use of RCA in precast/prestressed concrete structures was studied for the first time through the design, analysis, and testing of beam specimens as well as hollow-core slab specimens, which are structural elements commonly used in precast construction. This resulted in key intellectual outcomes on the effect of RCA on the bond strength of steel prestressing strand and rate of strength and stiffness gain of RCA concrete with time. Manufacturability, sustained service load behavior (including immediate and long term deflections), and ultimate load behavior (in bending, one-way shear, and two-way shear) of precast/prestressed concrete beams and hollow core slabs were minimally impacted for RCA replacement levels as high as 60% by volume. Furthermore, comparisons with current design methods and numerical models showed that the accuracy of the design and model predictions is not significantly affected by the use of RCA. Importantly, the genuine involvement of two prominent precast/prestressed concrete plants in the research increased likelihood of rapid technology transfer of the results to the industry.

The research constituted the first comprehensive study in the U.S. (including economic, environmental, and engineering aspects) on the structural use of RCA, thus providing long-range and transformative, seminal rather than incremental results with significant and direct implications for current and future research and practice in structural as well as materials engineering. Specifically, the research laid the foundation for the increased use of RCA to reduce the environmental impacts of reinforced concrete structures and can also serve as the basis for future codified regulatory standards for the use of RCA in structural reinforced concrete. This can result in the conservation of energy and protect the ecology of forested areas and riverbeds, thus providing service to society and contributing to public welfare. In addition to reducing overall project costs, the use of RCA in building construction may help earn LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) credits, both for incorporating recycled materials and for construction waste management, thus resulting in a cost-competitive alternative to conventional concrete.

The project played a significant role on the professional career development of the faculty principal investigator as a researcher and educator in engineering for structural sustainability, which is a relatively new field of study for him. Additional contributions and broader impacts to human resource development in science, engineering and technology included the involvement of two faculty (one assistant professor) and students from a predominantly undergraduate institution and one faculty (an assistant professor) and students from a Hispanic serving institution.  The project provided opportunities for the education and training of six graduate students (four underrepresented, with two females), six REU students (three underrepresented, with two females), and 16 other undergraduate students (eight underrepresented, with four females). Additionally, the project provided exposure to science and technology for K12 students and teachers and other non-scientist members of the public, including members of underrepresented groups. The project also provided the impetus and background for the requirement of utilizing recycled materials in the concrete materials competition as part of the 2015 Great Lakes Regional American Society of Civil Engineers Conference and formed the basis for a student activity on engineering recycled concrete as part of the course EG10112: Introduction to Engineering Systems II required of all freshmen in the College of Engineering at Notre Dame.


Last Modified: 11/28/2018
Modified by: Yahya C Kurama
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project, which was conducted at the University of Notre Dame in collaboration with the University of Texas at Tyler, involved fundamental research on the structural use of recycled concrete aggregates (RCA) as coarse aggregates in new reinforced concrete construction. Concrete is the most widely used material on earth (after water) and reinforced concrete is the most commonly used structural system for buildings. As aggregates (e.g., crushed limestone, gravel) constitute the largest volumetric component of concrete, the sustainability of our infrastructure can be enhanced significantly by reducing demand for virgin aggregates (reduce resource depletion) and increasing utilization of existing deteriorated infrastructure (increase resource reuse). Direct outcomes of the project included the development of performance-based RCA qualification requirements, concrete mix design guidelines and acceptance tests, and structural design/analysis/construction specifications to achieve acceptable fresh and hardened, short-term as well as long-term performance considering the variability of RCA properties in the U.S. These activities considering the current research needs resulted in new technical knowledge, physical resources, know-how, and human resources as described below. As one of the main intellectual outcomes, the project collected and tested the largest and most representative sample of RCA materials across the U.S., also making it the most geographically varied study of RCA known to the PIs. Using this data, predictive models previously developed for the compressive strength and stiffness of RCA concrete using materials from the Midwestern U.S. were extended to a much broader region of the country. The research constituted the first comprehensive study in the U.S. (including economic, environmental, and engineering aspects) on the structural use of RCA, thus providing long-range and transformative, seminal rather than incremental results with significant and direct implications for current and future research and practice in structural as well as materials engineering. Specifically, the research laid the foundation for the increased use of RCA to reduce the environmental impacts of reinforced concrete structures and can also serve as the basis for future codified regulatory standards for the use of RCA in structural reinforced concrete. This can result in the conservation of energy and protect the ecology of forested areas and riverbeds, thus providing service to society and contributing to public welfare. The project played a significant role on the professional career development of the faculty principal investigator as a researcher and educator in engineering for structural sustainability, which is a relatively new field of study for him. Additional contributions and broader impacts to human resource development in science, engineering and technology included the involvement of two faculty (one assistant professor) and students from a predominantly undergraduate institution and one faculty (an assistant professor) and students from a Hispanic serving institution. The project provided opportunities for the education and training of six graduate students (four underrepresented, with two females), six REU students (three underrepresented, with two females), and 16 other undergraduate students (eight underrepresented, with four females). Additionally, the project provided exposure to science and technology for K12 students and teachers and other non-scientist members of the public, including members of underrepresented groups. The project also provided the impetus and background for the requirement of utilizing recycled materials in the concrete materials competition as part of the 2015 Great Lakes Regional American Society of Civil Engineers Conference and formed the basis for a student activity on engineering recycled concrete as part of the course EG10112: Introduction to Engineering Systems II required of all freshmen in the College of Engineering at Notre Dame.
